meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To establish a court, having limited civil and criminal jurisdiction, to be known as the District Court, and to make provision for the jurisdiction, procedure and practice thereof and for purposes connected with the matters aforesaid.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the District Court Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: action (訴訟) means a civil proceeding commenced by writ of summons or in such manner as may be prescribed; (Amended 21 of 1962 s. 2)
authorized institution (認可機構) means an authorized institution within the meaning of section 2 of the Banking Ordinance (Cap. 155); (Added 28 of 2000 s. 3)
cause (訟案) means any action, suit or other original proceeding between a plaintiff and a defendant;
charging order (押記令) means an order under section 52A(1) to secure payment of a judgment or an order for the payment of money; (Added 28 of 2000 s. 3)
Court (區域法院) means the District Court established by section 3; (Added 21 of 1962 s. 2. Amended 28 of 2000 s. 48)
defendant (被告人) includes any person served with any writ of summons or process, or served with notice of, or entitled to attend, any proceedings;
deputy District Judge (地方法院暫委法官) means a deputy District Judge appointed under section 7; (Replaced 79 of 1981 s. 11)
functions (職能) includes powers and duties;
hereditament (可繼承產) includes both a corporeal and an incorporeal hereditament; (Added 21 of 1962 s. 2)
judge (法官) means a District Judge or a deputy District Judge; (Replaced 79 of 1981 s. 11)
judgment creditor (判定債權人) means a person in whose favour judgment has been entered or an order made in any court requiring a judgment debtor to pay money to the person; (Added 28 of 2000 s. 3)
judgment debtor (判定債務人) means a person against whom judgment has been entered or an order made in any court requiring him to pay money to another person; (Added 28 of 2000 s. 3)

land (土地) means land of whatever description, any part or section thereof, and tenements and buildings or parts of buildings (whether the division is horizontal, vertical or made in any other way); (Added 14 of 1973 s. 2)
matter (事宜) includes every proceeding in the Court not in a cause;
party (一方) includes every person served with notice of or attending any proceedings, although not named in the record;
personal injuries (人身傷害) includes any disease or any impairment of a person’s physical or mental condition; (Added 28 of 2000 s. 3)

plaintiff (原告人) includes every person asking for any relief (otherwise than by way of counterclaim as a defendant) against any other person by any form of proceeding, whether the proceeding is by action, suit, petition, motion, summons or otherwise;
Registrar (司法常務官) means the Registrar of the Court appointed under section 14 and includes a deputy registrar and assistant registrar appointed under that section; (Added 28 of 2000 s. 3)
Rules Committee (規則委員會) means the District Court Rules Committee established under section 17. (Added 21 of 1962 s. 2)
section.sourceNote: (1 of 1953 s. 2 incorporated. Amended 28 of 2000 s. 3)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Establishment of the District Court, and its general jurisdiction

subsection.content: A court known as the District Court is established. (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 4)

The Court shall be a court of record and shall have such civil and criminal jurisdiction and powers as are conferred upon it by this Ordinance and by any other enactment for the time being in force. (Amended 21 of 1962 s. 3)

The jurisdiction and powers conferred by any other enactment for the time being in force shall be subject only to such limitations as such enactment may provide or may have provided. (Added 20 of 1963 s. 3)
The Court shall consist of 2 or more judges, to be known as District Judges.
District Judges shall be appointed by the Chief Executive by instrument under the Public Seal. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

Any appointment made under the provisions of subsection (2) may be given effect from a date anterior to that of the instrument by which it is made. (Added 18 of 1958 s. 2. Amended 20 of 1972 s. 24; 28 of 2000 s. 5)

This section does not authorize the discharge of any judicial functions by any person before the date of the instrument of appointment or before the requirements of section 17 of the Oaths and Declarations Ordinance (Cap. 11) have been fulfilled. (Added 28 of 2000 s. 5)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Professional qualifications of District Judges

subsection.leadIn: No person shall be appointed to be a District Judge under section 4 unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is qualified to practise as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in a court in Hong Kong or any other common law jurisdiction having unlimited jurisdiction either in civil or criminal matters; and (Amended 21 of 1962 s. 4; 14 of 1997 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: since becoming so qualified he has for a period of or periods totalling not less than 5 years—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: practised as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in such a court; or

subparagraph.name: ia
subparagraph.content: been the Registrar of the High Court or a senior deputy registrar, deputy registrar or assistant registrar of the High Court, appointed in accordance with section 37 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4); or (Added 10 of 2005 s. 144)

subparagraph.name: ib
subparagraph.content: been the Registrar or a deputy registrar or assistant registrar appointed in accordance with section 14; or (Added 10 of 2005 s. 144)

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: been a permanent magistrate appointed in accordance with section 5 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227); or

subparagraph.name: va
subparagraph.content: been a coroner appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Coroners Ordinance (Cap. 504); or (Added 10 of 2005 s. 144)

subparagraph.name: vb
subparagraph.content: been an adjudicator appointed in accordance with section 4 of the Small Claims Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 338); or (Added 10 of 2005 s. 144)

subparagraph.name: vc
subparagraph.content: been a presiding officer appointed in accordance with section 4 of the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25); or (Added 10 of 2005 s. 144)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: been a legal officer as defined in section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87); or

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: been the Director of Legal Aid or a Deputy Director of Legal Aid, Assistant Director of Legal Aid or Legal Aid Officer, appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91); or (Added 66 of 1976 s. 2. Amended 24 of 1983 s. 7; 39 of 1992 s. 13)

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: been the Official Receiver or an Assistant Official Receiver (Legal), Assistant Principal Solicitor, Senior Solicitor or Solicitor, appointed in accordance with section 75 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or (Added 39 of 1992 s. 13. Amended 60 of 1992 s. 7; 68 of 1995 s. 18)

subparagraph.name: x
subparagraph.content: been the Director of Intellectual Property or a Deputy Director of Intellectual Property, Assistant Director of Intellectual Property, Assistant Principal Solicitor, Senior Solicitor or Solicitor, appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Director of Intellectual Property (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 412). (Added 60 of 1992 s. 7. Amended 26 of 2012 s. 40)

subsection.content: For the purpose of calculating such period of 5 years, periods of less than 5 years falling within any of the sub-paragraphs of paragraph (b) of subsection (1) may be combined. (Amended 38 of 1965 s. 2)

For the purposes of calculating the period of 5 years under subsection (1), periods served in an office specified in Part I of the First Schedule to the repealed Registrar General (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 100) may be taken into account notwithstanding the repeal of that Ordinance. (Added 8 of 1993 s. 26)

section.sourceNote: (1 of 1953 s. 5 incorporated. Amended 10 of 2005 s. 144)

subsection.content: A judge sitting alone shall, subject to section 58 and to the rules, hear and dispose of proceedings in the Court and business arising out of the proceedings. (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 6)

The proceedings in every action or matter subsequent to the hearing or trial, down to and including the final judgment or order, and any application for leave to appeal or for a stay of execution shall, so far as is practicable and convenient, be taken before the judge or Registrar before whom the trial or hearing took place. (Replaced 21 of 1962 s. 5. Amended 28 of 2000 s. 6)

The business of the Court shall be heard and disposed of in court unless this Ordinance, the rules of court or another enactment authorizes the matter to be heard and disposed of in chambers. (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may appoint a person who is eligible under section 5 to be appointed as a District Judge to be a deputy District Judge if— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 145)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the office of any District Judge becomes vacant for any reason; or (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 145)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he considers that the interests of the administration of justice require that a deputy District Judge should be appointed temporarily.

subsection.content: A deputy District Judge shall have and may exercise all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges and perform all the duties of a District Judge. A reference in any law to a deputy District Judge shall be construed accordingly. (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 145)

subsection.leadIn: Without restricting the Chief Justice’s power under subsection (1), the Chief Justice may appoint a deputy District Judge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a specified case or class of cases only;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a specified period only.

subsection.content: The Chief Justice may terminate the appointment of a deputy District Judge at any time.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Power of deputy District Judge in part-heard cases
section.content: A deputy District Judge may resume the hearing and determine any adjourned proceedings and to deliver judgment even if the period of his appointment as a deputy District Judge has expired or his appointment has been terminated by the Chief Justice.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Jurisdiction in part-heard cases of magistrates appointed to be judges
section.content: Where a magistrate is appointed to be a judge he may, notwithstanding such appointment, exercise and discharge all such jurisdiction, powers, authorities and duties as were prior to such appointment vested in him as a magistrate, but in relation only to any proceedings which were duly commenced before him in his capacity as a magistrate prior to such appointment.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Jurisdiction in part-heard cases of judges appointed to be High Court Judges or Court of First Instance deputy judges

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be a judge of the High Court under section 6(1) of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be a deputy judge of the Court of First Instance under section 10(1) of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4),

section.continued: he may, notwithstanding such appointment, exercise and discharge all such jurisdiction, powers, authorities and duties as were prior to such appointment vested in him as a judge of the Court, but in relation only to any proceedings which were duly commenced before him in his capacity as such judge prior to such appointment.

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Term of office of District Judges

subsection.content: A judge must vacate his office when he attains the retirement age.

Notwithstanding the fact that he has attained the retirement age, a person holding the office of a judge may continue in office for so long after attaining the retirement age as may be necessary to enable him to deliver judgment or to do any other thing in relation to proceedings that were commenced before him before he attained that age.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) applies to a judge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is subject to the retirement age (extension) arrangement under section 5A of the Pension Benefits (Judicial Officers) Ordinance (Cap. 401); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who, pursuant to the Circular, has opted for the retirement age (extension) arrangement. (Added 10 of 2019 s. 6)

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (1), the term of office of a judge may be extended for a specified period or periods not exceeding 5 years in the aggregate by the Chief Executive acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission, and in any such case the judge is accordingly to be regarded as having attained the retirement age at the expiration of the specified period or periods. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
A judge may at any time resign his office by notice in writing addressed to the Chief Executive. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Circular (《通告》) means a Circular issued by the Chief Justice on the details of the retirement age (extension) arrangement for judicial officers engaged on terms that do not attract pension benefits under the Pension Benefits (Judicial Officers) Ordinance (Cap. 401);
judge (法官) means a District Judge;
retirement age (退休年齡) means the age of 65 years;

retirement age (extension) arrangement (退休年齡(延展)安排) means the arrangements in relation to the extension of the ages of retirement and terms of office for judicial officers as provided by the amendments contained in the Judicial Officers (Extension of Retirement Age) (Amendment) Ordinance 2019 (10 of 2019). (Replaced 10 of 2019 s. 6)

section.name: s12
section.heading: Distribution and disposal of business of the Court

subsection.content: Subject to any rules made under this Ordinance, the Chief Justice may give such directions as he thinks fit touching the distribution and disposal of the business of the Court.

Subject to any such rules or directions and to the provisions of subsection (3), a judge shall sit for the disposal of business pending in the Court at such places and times as he may think fit. (Amended 21 of 1962 s. 7)

Any proceedings may at any time and at any stage thereof, and either with or without application from any of the parties thereto, be transferred in such manner as may be prescribed or as any such direction may authorize, from one judge to another. (Amended 21 of 1962 s. 7)
The Court shall use such seal as the Chief Justice directs.
All writs, judgments, orders, documents and copies issued by the Court shall be sealed with the seal.
A writ, judgment, order, document or copy purporting to be sealed with the seal of the Court is admissible in any court on its production without further proof.

The Chief Executive may appoint a registrar of the Court and such number of deputy registrars, assistant registrars, chief judicial clerks and bailiffs as he may think fit; and there may be attached to such court such number of clerks of the Court, clerks, interpreters and other officers as the Chief Executive may consider necessary.(Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 9)

In addition to any functions, powers and duties which he is by this or any other enactment enabled to exercise or required to discharge, the Registrar, and every deputy registrar, assistant registrar, bailiff, clerk of the Court, clerk, interpreter and other officer appointed or attached to the Court under the provisions of subsection (1) may exercise and discharge the like functions, powers and duties respectively insofar as the same are applicable to the business and proceedings of the Court, as those exercised and discharged by a registrar, deputy registrar, assistant registrar, bailiff, clerk of the Court, clerk, interpreter or other officer attached to the High Court.(Replaced 21 of 1962 s. 9. Amended 38 of 1965 s. 3; 92 of 1975 s. 58)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The Registrar shall have and may exercise and discharge such other jurisdiction, powers and duties as may be conferred or imposed on him by or under rules of court or any other law.(Added 28 of 2000 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.content: The deputy registrars and assistant registrars may be called Masters.(Added 28 of 2000 s. 9)

Any act which under this or any other enactment is required or authorized to be done by the Registrar may be performed by a deputy registrar or assistant registrar of the Court; and any process of the Court may be executed by any bailiff thereof notwithstanding that it may have been directed personally to some other bailiff.(Amended 21 of 1962 s. 9; 38 of 1965 s. 3)

It shall be lawful, in relation to the business and proceedings of the Court, for the Registrar of the High Court and every temporary registrar, senior deputy registrar, temporary senior deputy registrar, deputy registrar, temporary deputy registrar, assistant registrar, temporary assistant registrar and bailiff attached to the High Court to exercise any power or discharge any duty which such Registrar, temporary registrar, senior deputy registrar, temporary senior deputy registrar, deputy registrar, temporary deputy registrar, assistant registrar, temporary assistant registrar or bailiff might respectively have exercised or discharged under subsections (2) and (3) if he had been appointed or attached to the Court under subsection (1).(Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 9. Amended 10 of 2005 s. 146)

In the exercise of his powers and discharge of his duties under this Ordinance, any person to whom this section applies shall be subject to the same liabilities and penalties and have the benefit of the same protection as attach by virtue of the provisions of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) to a person exercising or discharging similar powers or duties under that Ordinance.(Amended 21 of 1962 s. 9; 28 of 2000 s. 9)

section.name: s14AA
section.heading: Professional qualifications of Registrar, deputy registrars and assistant registrars

subsection.leadIn: A person shall be eligible to be appointed as the Registrar, a deputy registrar or an assistant registrar if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is qualified to practise as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in a court in Hong Kong or any other common law jurisdiction having unlimited jurisdiction either in civil or criminal matters; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: since becoming so qualified, he has for a period of or periods totalling not less than 5 years—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: practised as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in such a court;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: been a permanent magistrate appointed in accordance with section 5 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: been a coroner appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Coroners Ordinance (Cap. 504);

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: been an adjudicator appointed in accordance with section 4 of the Small Claims Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 338);

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: been a presiding officer appointed in accordance with section 4 of the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25);

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: been a legal officer as defined in section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87);

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: been the Director of Legal Aid or a Deputy Director of Legal Aid, Assistant Director of Legal Aid or Legal Aid Officer, appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91);

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: been the Official Receiver or an Assistant Official Receiver (Legal), Assistant Principal Solicitor, Senior Solicitor or Solicitor, appointed in accordance with section 75 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: been the Director of Intellectual Property or a Deputy Director of Intellectual Property, Assistant Director of Intellectual Property, Assistant Principal Solicitor, Senior Solicitor or Solicitor, appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Director of Intellectual Property (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 412). (Amended 26 of 2012 s. 41)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of calculating the period of 5 years referred to in subsection (1)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: periods of less than 5 years falling within any of the subparagraphs of that subsection may be combined;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: periods served in an office specified in Part I of the First Schedule to the repealed Registrar General (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 100) may be taken into account notwithstanding the repeal of that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may appoint a person who is eligible under section 14AA to be appointed as the Registrar to be a temporary registrar if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the office of the Registrar becomes vacant for any reason; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he considers that the interest of the administration of justice requires that a temporary registrar should be appointed.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the generality of the power conferred on him by subsection (1), the Chief Justice may appoint a temporary registrar for a specified period only.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: A temporary registrar has, during the period for which he or she is appointed, all the jurisdiction, privileges, powers and duties of the Registrar and a reference in any law to the Registrar is to be construed accordingly. (Added 17 of 2018 s. 10)
The Chief Justice may terminate the appointment of a temporary registrar at any time.

subsection.def: In this section and section 14C, temporary registrar (暫委司法常務官) means a person appointed under subsection (1) to be a temporary registrar.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may appoint a person who is eligible under section 14AA to be appointed as a deputy registrar to be a temporary deputy registrar if— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 148)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the office of any deputy registrar becomes vacant for any reason; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he considers that the interest of the administration of justice requires that a temporary deputy registrar should be appointed.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the generality of the power conferred on him by subsection (1), the Chief Justice may appoint a temporary deputy registrar for a specified period only.

A temporary deputy registrar shall, during the period for which he is appointed, have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges, and discharge all the duties of a deputy registrar and any reference in any law to a deputy registrar shall be construed accordingly.
The Chief Justice may terminate the appointment of a temporary deputy registrar at any time.
A temporary deputy registrar may be called Master.

subsection.def: In this section and section 14C, temporary deputy registrar (暫委副司法常務官) means a person appointed under subsection (1) to be a temporary deputy registrar.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may appoint a person who is eligible under section 14AA to be appointed as an assistant registrar to be a temporary assistant registrar if— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 149)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the office of any assistant registrar becomes vacant for any reason; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he considers that the interest of the administration of justice requires that a temporary assistant registrar should be appointed.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the generality of the power conferred on him by subsection (1), the Chief Justice may appoint a temporary assistant registrar for a specified period only.

A temporary assistant registrar shall, during the period for which he is appointed, have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges, and discharge all the duties of an assistant registrar and any reference in any law to an assistant registrar shall be construed accordingly.
The Chief Justice may terminate the appointment of a temporary assistant registrar at any time.
A temporary assistant registrar may be called Master.

subsection.def: In this section and section 14C, temporary assistant registrar (暫委助理司法常務官) means a person appointed under subsection (1) to be a temporary assistant registrar.

section.name: s14C
section.heading: Powers of temporary registrars, etc. in case which is part-heard on termination of appointment

subsection.content: If the hearing of any proceedings before a temporary registrar is adjourned or if he reserves judgment in any proceedings, the temporary registrar shall have power to resume the hearing and determine the proceedings or deliver judgment, notwithstanding that his appointment as a temporary registrar has expired or has been terminated.
Subsection (1) shall apply to a temporary deputy registrar or temporary assistant registrar as it applies to a temporary registrar.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings in the Court, any of the following persons may address the Court, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any party to the proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a barrister qualified to practise in the High Court and retained by or on behalf of any party; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a solicitor qualified to practise in the High Court and acting generally in the proceedings for a party thereto, but not a solicitor retained as an advocate by a solicitor so acting; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other person allowed by leave of the Court to appear instead of a party to the proceedings. (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 11)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The right of a solicitor to address the Court is not excluded by reason only of the fact that he is in the permanent and exclusive employment of any other solicitor. (Added 28 of 2000 s. 11)

No person other than a solicitor shall be entitled to have or to recover any fee or reward for appearing or acting on behalf of any other party in any proceedings in the Court. (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 11)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The right of a barrister to appear or to act in the Court or of a solicitor to recover costs for the employment of a barrister to appear or to act is not affected by anything in this Ordinance. (Added 28 of 2000 s. 11)

section.name: s16
section.heading: Prohibition of proceedings in error
section.content: No proceedings in error shall be taken upon any proceeding under the provisions of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: There is to be a District Court Rules Committee. (Replaced 17 of 2018 s. 12)

content.leadIn: The Rules Committee is to consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 3 District Judges appointed by the Chief Judge;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a barrister nominated by the Hong Kong Bar Association;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a solicitor nominated by The Law Society of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Secretary for Justice or a legal officer, as defined in section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87), appointed by the Secretary for Justice. (Added 17 of 2018 s. 12)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: The Registrar is to be the secretary of the Rules Committee. (Added 17 of 2018 s. 12)
At any meeting of the Rules Committee, 4 members, one of whom is either such a barrister or such a solicitor, shall be a quorum. (Amended 17 of 2018 s. 12)
The Rules Committee shall be convened by or at the direction of the Chief Judge.
The Chairman of the Rules Committee shall be the Chief Judge or, in his absence, the senior District Judge present at the meeting.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Provisions Applicable to both Civil and Criminal Proceedings

section.name: s18
section.heading: Transfer of unclaimed moneys in Court

subsection.content: When any sum of money remains unclaimed in the Court for a period of 5 years, the Chief Justice may, on application by the Registrar of the High Court, order such sum to be transferred to the general revenue of the Government. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
Before making any order under subsection (1) the Chief Justice may direct that such notice, if any, as he thinks necessary shall be given and to such parties as he may think fit.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Committal for contempt

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: wilfully insults a judge or a witness or any officer of the Court during his sitting or attendance in court, or in going to or returning from the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: wilfully interrupts the proceedings of the Court or commits contempt of the Court or otherwise misbehaves in court,

section.continued: any officer of the Court, with or without the assistance of any other person may, by order of the judge, take the offender into custody and detain him until the rising of the Court and the judge may if he thinks fit—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: by a warrant under his hand commit the offender to prison for a specified period not exceeding 2 years; or (Amended 25 of 1972 s. 2)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: impose upon the offender a fine for every such offence. (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 12)

section.name: s22
section.heading: Enforcement of liability for fees
section.content: In default of the payment of any fees which have been prescribed, payment thereof shall be enforced, by order of the Court, in like manner as payment of any debt adjudged by the Court to be paid.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Enforcement of fines and forfeited recognizances

subsection.content: The Court may enforce a fine imposed, or a recognizance forfeited, by it in the same manner as a judgment for the payment of money.

The Court shall certify to the Registrar the sum payable if a fine or recognizance is not paid in full when it is due and the Registrar shall enforce the payment of the sum certified as a judgment debt due to the Court.

subsection.def: In this section, fine (罰款) includes a penalty imposed in civil proceedings and payable to the Court.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Enforcement of orders and warrants for imprisonment
section.leadIn: Whenever any order or warrant for the committal of any person to prison is made or issued by the Court or a judge, the order or warrant shall be directed to the Registrar who shall thereby be empowered to take the body of the person against whom the order is made on the warrant issued and it shall be the duty—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of every police officer to assist in the execution of every such order or warrant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of the officer in charge of the prison mentioned in any such order or warrant to receive and keep the person therein mentioned until he is lawfully discharged.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Registrar to take charge of fees, etc.
section.leadIn: There shall be paid to the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all fees payable under this Ordinance or under any other enactment, in respect of any proceedings in the Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all forfeitures so imposed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all fines so imposed. (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 14)

section.name: s27
section.heading: Falsely pretending to act under authority of the Court

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: delivers or causes to be delivered to any other person any paper falsely purporting to be a copy of any summons or other process of the Court, knowing it to be false; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: acts or professes to act under any false colour or pretence of the process or authority of the Court,

section.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 16)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 7 years.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Falsely representing documents to have been issued from the Court
section.content: Without prejudice to the provisions of section 27 any person who knowingly delivers or causes to be delivered to any person any document which not having been issued under the authority of the Court has, by reason of its form or contents or both, the appearance of having been issued under such authority shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 12 months.
section.sourceNote: (Replaced 21 of 1962 s. 12. Amended L.N. 446 of 1994; L.N. 307 of 1998; 28 of 2000 s. 17)

section.name: s29
section.heading: Rescuing goods
section.leadIn: Any person who rescues or attempts to rescue any goods seized in execution under process of the Court or seized under a distress for rent shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 18)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years. (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 18)

section.name: s30
section.heading: Assaulting officers
section.leadIn: Any person who assaults, resists or obstructs an officer of the Court while in the execution of his duty shall be liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 19)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years. (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 19)

section.name: s31
section.heading: Revocation of committal order
section.content: A judge may at any time revoke an order committing a person to prison under section 20 or 23 and, if he is already in custody, order his discharge.

part.name: P4
part.heading: Civil Jurisdiction and Procedure

section.name: s32
section.heading: General jurisdiction in actions of contract, quasi-contract and tort

subsection.content: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any action founded on contract, quasi-contract or tort where the amount of the plaintiff’s claim does not exceed $3,000,000.

subsection.leadIn: In this section and in section 34, the amount of the plaintiff’s claim means the amount the plaintiff claims after taking into account—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any set-off or any debt or demand the defendant claims or may recover from the plaintiff;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any compensation, as defined in section 3 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282), paid to the plaintiff under that Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any contributory negligence,

subsection.continued: that the plaintiff admits in his statement of claim.

subsection.content: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any proceedings by way of interpleader in which the amount or value of the matter in dispute does not exceed $3,000,000.

section.sourceNote: (Replaced 28 of 2000 s. 21. Amended L.N. 241 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2018)

section.name: s33
section.heading: Money recoverable by enactment

subsection.leadIn: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any action for the recovery of any penalty, expenses, contribution or other like demand which is recoverable by virtue of any enactment for the time being in force and for the recovery of any sum which is declared by any enactment to be recoverable as a civil debt if— (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 22)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is not expressly provided by that or any other enactment that the demand shall be recoverable only in some other court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount claimed in the action does not exceed $3,000,000. (Amended 35 of 1966 s. 2; 68 of 1973 s. 2; 79 of 1981 s. 2; L.N. 387 of 1983; 49 of 1988 s. 4; L.N. 241 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2018)

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section, penalty (罰金) does not include a fine to which any person is liable on conviction on indictment or on summary conviction.

section.sourceNote: (22 of 1962 s. 4 incorporated. Amended 28 of 2000 s. 22)

section.name: s34
section.heading: Abandonment of part of claim to give Court jurisdiction

subsection.content: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine an action that is in excess of the Court’s monetary jurisdiction limit on the plaintiff abandoning the amount of the plaintiff’s claim in excess and the action is one in which the Court otherwise has jurisdiction.
The Court cannot award to the plaintiff in an action under this section an amount exceeding the Court’s monetary jurisdiction limit for the action.
The judgment of the Court in an action limited under this section is in full discharge of all demands in the cause of action.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Jurisdiction for recovery of land
section.content: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any action for the recovery of land, where the annual rent or the rateable value of the land, determined in accordance with the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116), or the annual value of the land, whichever is the least, does not exceed $320,000.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Jurisdiction where title in question
section.leadIn: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any action which would otherwise be within the jurisdiction of the Court and in which the title to an interest in land comes into question if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for an easement or licence, the rateable value, determined in accordance with the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116) or the annual value, whichever is the less, of the land, over which the easement or licence is claimed, does not exceed $320,000; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for any other case, the rateable value, determined in accordance with the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116) or the annual value, whichever is the less, of the land, does not exceed $320,000.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the maximum limits in amount or value set out in subsection (2), the Court has the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance to hear and determine the following proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceedings relating to or for the administration of the estate of a deceased person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings for the execution of a trust or for the declaration that a trust subsists or proceedings under section 3 of the Variation of Trusts Ordinance (Cap. 253);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: proceedings for the foreclosure or redemption of a mortgage or for enforcing a charge or lien;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: proceedings for the specific performance, or for the rectification, rescission or delivery up or cancellation of an agreement for the sale, purchase or lease of property;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: proceedings for the maintenance or advancement of an infant;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: proceedings for the dissolution or winding up of a partnership, whether or not the existence of the partnership is in dispute;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: proceedings for relief against fraud or mistake.

subsection.leadIn: The maximum limits in amount or value referred to in subsection (1) for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(a), an estate of a deceased person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(b), an estate or fund subject or alleged to be subject to the trust;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(c), the amount owing under the mortgage, charge or lien;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(d), for an agreement for sale or purchase, the purchase money or, for an agreement for lease, the value of the property;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(e), the property of the infant;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(f), the assets of the partnership;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(g), the damage sustained or the estate or fund for which relief is sought,

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: $3,000,000, where the proceedings do not involve or relate to land; (Amended L.N. 241 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2018)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: $3,000,000, where the proceedings partly involve or partly relate to land and the part that does not so involve or does not so relate exceeds $3,000,000 in amount or value; (Amended L.N. 241 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2018)

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: $7,000,000, where the proceedings wholly involve or wholly relate to land; (Amended L.N. 131 of 2018)

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: $7,000,000, where the proceedings partly involve or partly relate to land and the part that does not so involve or does not so relate does not exceed $3,000,000 in amount or value. (Amended L.N. 241 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2018)

subsection.content: A judge has in proceedings authorized by this section in addition to his other powers and authority the powers and authorities of a judge of the Court of First Instance acting in the exercise of the equitable jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance.

Nothing in this section gives jurisdiction to the Court in proceedings for the recovery of land or relating to the title to land, where the annual rent or the rateable value of the land, determined in accordance with the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116), or the annual value of the land, whichever is the least, exceeds $320,000. (Amended L.N. 131 of 2018)

section.name: s38
section.heading: Jurisdiction under the Married Persons Status Ordinance
section.content: The Court has the jurisdiction and powers of the Court of First Instance conferred by section 6 of the Married Persons Status Ordinance (Cap. 182).

section.name: s38A
section.heading: Execution of instruments by order of the Court

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the Court has given or made a judgment or order directing a person to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: execute any conveyance, contract or other document; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: endorse any negotiable instrument; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: neglects or refuses to comply with the judgment or order; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: cannot, after reasonable inquiry, be found.

subsection.content: The Court may, on such terms and conditions, if any, as may be just, order that the conveyance, contract or other document is to be executed, or that the negotiable instrument is to be endorsed, by such person as the Court may nominate for that purpose.

A conveyance, contract, document or instrument executed or endorsed in accordance with subsection (2) has the same effect as if it had been executed or endorsed by the person originally directed to execute or endorse it.
Nothing in this section abridges the powers of the Court to proceed by attachment against any person neglecting or refusing to execute or endorse any such instrument.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Counterclaims
section.content: In sections 32 to 37, references to an action or proceeding are to be construed as including references to a counterclaim.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Saving
section.content: This Part does not affect the provisions of the Small Claims Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 338), the Landlord and Tenant (Consolidation) Ordinance (Cap. 7) or the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25) or any other Ordinance conferring exclusive jurisdiction on a court or tribunal other than the Court.

part.crossHeading: Transfer of Proceedings and Miscellaneous Provisions as to Jurisdiction

section.name: s41
section.heading: Procedure where proceedings beyond the jurisdiction of the Court are commenced in the Court

subsection.content: The Court shall, either of its own motion or on the application of any party, order that an action or proceeding be transferred to the Court of First Instance where an action or proceeding commenced in the Court, not being a counterclaim, is outside the jurisdiction of the Court but is within the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance.

The Court may, if it thinks fit, instead of ordering that the action or proceeding be transferred, order that it be struck out where, on the application of a defendant, it appears to the Court that the plaintiff or, if more than one, one of the plaintiffs knew or ought to have known that the Court had no jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: If a defendant in an action or proceeding within the jurisdiction of the Court makes a counterclaim which is not within the jurisdiction of the Court but within the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance, the Court may, either of its own motion or on the application of any party, order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the whole proceedings be transferred to the Court of First Instance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the proceedings on the counterclaim be transferred to the Court of First Instance; and the proceedings on the plaintiff’s claim, except for a defence of set-off as to the whole or a part of the subject matter of the counterclaim, be heard and determined by the Court; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the Court considers the whole proceedings should be heard and determined in the Court, that the matter be reported to the Court of First Instance or a judge thereof.

subsection.leadIn: On the receipt of a report mentioned in subsection (3)(c), the Court of First Instance or a judge thereof may, as it or he thinks fit, order either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the whole proceedings be transferred to the Court of First Instance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the whole proceedings be heard and determined in the Court; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the proceedings on the counterclaim be transferred to the Court of First Instance; and the proceedings on the plaintiff’s claim, except for a defence of set-off as to the whole or a part of the subject matter of the counterclaim, be heard and determined by the Court.

subsection.content: Where an order is made under subsection (3)(b) or subsection (4)(c) and judgment on the claim is given for the plaintiff, execution thereon shall, unless the Court of First Instance or a judge thereof at any time otherwise orders, be stayed until the proceedings transferred to the Court of First Instance have been concluded.

If no report is made under subsection (3)(c), or if on any such report it is ordered that the whole proceedings be heard and determined in the Court, the Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the whole proceedings notwithstanding any enactment to the contrary.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Transfer of proceedings to the Court of First Instance or the Lands Tribunal
section.content: The Court may, either of its own motion or on the application of any party, order at any stage the transfer to the Court of First Instance or the Lands Tribunal of all or part of any action or proceedings before it which are within the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance or the Lands Tribunal, as the case may be.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Transfer to the Court from the Court of First Instance of proceedings within the jurisdiction of the Court

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may, either of its own motion or on the application of any party, order the transfer to the Court of all or part of an action or proceeding, other than a counterclaim, which appears to the Court of First Instance likely to be within the jurisdiction of the Court.
An order may be made under this section at any stage of the proceedings of the motion of the Court of First Instance itself or on the application of any party.

The Court of First Instance is required to make an order under this section unless it is of the opinion that, by reason of the importance or complexity of any issue arising in the action or proceeding, or for any other reason, the action or proceeding ought to remain in the Court of First Instance.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Transfer to the Court from the Court of First Instance where the parties consent

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may, if the parties consent, order the transfer to the Court of all or part of an action or proceeding, including a counterclaim, which is outside the jurisdiction of the Court, but would have been within its jurisdiction except for the monetary limits specified in section 32, 33, 35, 36 or 37.
An order may be made under this section at any stage of the proceedings.

Upon a transfer under subsection (1), the Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine all or part of an action or proceeding, including a counterclaim, so transferred notwithstanding any enactment to the contrary.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to an action or proceeding transferred—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from the Court of First Instance to the Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from the Court to the Court of First Instance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: from a tribunal to the Court.

subsection.content: The court or tribunal that orders the transfer may make an order for costs prior to the transfer and of the transfer of proceedings.

The costs of the whole proceedings both before and after the transfer are in the discretion of the court to which the proceedings are transferred subject to any order made by the court or tribunal which ordered the transfer.

The court to which the proceedings are transferred has power to order costs and order the scales on which the costs of the several parts of the proceedings are to be taxed. The costs of the whole proceedings are to be taxed in the court to which the proceedings are transferred.

In an action founded on contract, quasi-contract or tort, for the proceedings in the Court of First Instance before the transfer, the Court may, if satisfied that there was sufficient reason for bringing the action in the Court of First Instance and subject to any order of the Court of First Instance, allow costs on the Court of First Instance scale.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Division of causes of action
section.content: No cause of action shall be split or divided so as to be made the ground of 2 or more different actions for the purpose of bringing 2 or more actions in the Court.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Infancy no defence
section.leadIn: No person shall by reason of his not having attained the full age of 21 years be exempted from liability for any debt, damages or demand arising under an agreement made before the date of commencement# of the Age of Majority (Related Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 410) where the debt, damages or demand—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does not exceed the sum of $60,000; or (Added 49 of 1988 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been reduced to a sum not exceeding $60,000 by reason of the plaintiff having abandoned the amount in excess of $60,000 in his cause of action. (Added 49 of 1988 s. 4)

section.sourceNote: (22 of 1962 s. 17 incorporated. Amended 49 of 1988 s. 4; 32 of 1990 s. 18)

section.name: s47A
section.heading: Power of the Court to order disclosure, etc. of documents before commencement of proceedings

subsection.content: A person who appears to the Court to be likely to be a party to subsequent proceedings may apply to the Court for an order for discovery of documents against a person who is likely to be a party to the proceedings and who has in his possession, custody or power documents directly relevant to an issue arising out of the claim. (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 15)
The application is to be made in accordance with rules of court.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may order the person, if it appears to it that the person is likely to have or to have had in his possession, custody or power any directly relevant documents— (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 15)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to disclose whether those documents are in his possession, custody or power; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to produce the documents in his possession, custody or power to the applicant or, on the conditions specified in the order—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the applicant’s legal advisers;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to the applicant’s legal advisers and a medical or other professional adviser of the applicant; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the applicant has no legal adviser, to a medical or other professional adviser of the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (3), a document is only to be regarded as directly relevant to an issue arising out of a claim in the anticipated proceedings if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the document would be likely to be relied on in evidence by any party in the proceedings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the document supports or adversely affects any party’s case. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 15)

section.name: s47B
section.heading: Extension of powers of the Court to order disclosure of documents, inspection of property, etc.

subsection.content: A party to proceedings in an action, in which a claim is made, may apply to the Court in accordance with rules of court for an order for discovery of documents against a person who is not a party to the proceedings and who is likely to have or to have had in his possession, custody or power documents relevant to an issue arising out of the claim. (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 20)

subsection.leadIn: The Court may order the person, if it appears to it that the person is likely to have or to have had in his possession, custody or power any relevant documents—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to disclose whether those documents are in his possession, custody or power; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to produce the documents in his possession, custody or power to the applicant or, on the conditions specified in the order—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the applicant’s legal advisers;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to the applicant’s legal advisers and a medical or other professional adviser of the applicant; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the applicant has no legal adviser, to a medical or other professional adviser of the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: A party to proceedings in an action, in which a claim is made, may apply to the Court for an order against a person who is not a party to the proceedings for, and the Court may order— (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 20)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the inspection, photographing, preservation, custody and detention of property which is not the property of, or in the possession of, a party to the proceedings but which is the subject-matter of the proceedings or as to which any question arises in the proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the taking of samples of the property mentioned in paragraph (a) and the carrying out of any experiment on or with the property.

subsection.content: An application under this section is to be made in accordance with rules of court.
The powers in this section are in addition to the power of the Court to make orders which is exercisable apart from this section.

subsection.def: In this section, property (財產) includes any land, chattel or other physical property of any description.

subsection.content: The power to make rules of court includes power to make rules of court as to the circumstances in which an order under section 47A or 47B can be made.
Rules may include the incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions which the Rules Committee may consider necessary or expedient.
The Court shall award costs of and incidental to the proceedings to the person against whom an order is sought under sections 47A and 47B unless the Court otherwise directs.

section.name: s47D
section.heading: Powers of the Court exercisable before commencement of action

subsection.leadIn: A person authorized by the rules may, in proceedings in an action, in which a claim is made, apply to the Court for an order for and the Court may order— (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 16)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the inspection, photographing, preservation, custody and detention of property which may become the subject-matter of the proceedings or as to which any question may arise in the proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the taking of samples of the property mentioned in paragraph (a) and the carrying out of any experiment on or with the property.

subsection.content: An application under this section is to be made in accordance with rules of court.

subsection.leadIn: Rules may be made to include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the manner in which an application for an order can be made and by whom;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which an order can be made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions which the Rules Committee may consider necessary or expedient.

subsection.def: In this section, property (財產) includes any land, chattel or other physical property of any description.

section.name: s47E
section.heading: Application to Government of sections 47A to 47D

subsection.content: Section 47D binds the Government so far as it relates to property (within the meaning of that section) which appears to the Court to be likely to become the subject-matter of subsequent proceedings. (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 21)
Sections 47A, 47B and 47C bind the Government.
The Court shall not make an order under section 47A, 47B or 47D if it considers that compliance with an order would be likely to be injurious to the public interest.

part.crossHeading: Exercise of Jurisdiction and Ancillary Jurisdiction

subsection.leadIn: The Court has the same power as the Court of First Instance in any proceedings before it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to grant the relief, redress, or remedy or combination of remedies, either absolute or conditional; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to section 46, to give effect to every ground of defence or counterclaim, equitable or legal,

subsection.continued: which ought to be granted or given.

subsection.content: The Court has to administer law and equity so that, if there is a conflict or variance between the rules of equity and the rules of the common law referring to the same matter, the rules of equity prevail.

subsection.leadIn: The Court has to give the same effect as in the past—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to equitable estates, titles, rights, relieves, defences and counterclaims, and to equitable duties and liabilities; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (a), to legal claims and demands and estates, titles, rights, duties, obligations, and liabilities existing by the common law or by any custom or created by an Ordinance.

subsection.content: The Court has to exercise its jurisdiction to secure that, as far as possible, all matters in dispute between the parties are completely and finally determined, and multiplicity of legal proceedings on any of those matters is avoided.
The Court may stay any proceedings before it, where it thinks fit to do so, either of its own motion or on the application of any person, whether or not a party to the proceedings.

section.name: s48A
section.heading: Power to award damages as well as, or in substitution for, injunction or specific performance
section.content: The Court may award damages in addition to or in substitution for an injunction or specific performance where it has jurisdiction to entertain an application for an injunction or specific performance.

section.name: s48B
section.heading: Contempt of Court
section.leadIn: A judge has the powers of a judge of the Court of First Instance to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: punish for disobedience of a judgment or order of the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: punish for breach of undertaking; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: discipline or punish for breach of a duty imposed upon a solicitor by rules of court.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Interest on claims for debt and damages

subsection.leadIn: The Court may include simple interest, at the rate the Court thinks fit in a judgment for a debt or damages, on the debt or damages or on a payment made before judgment, for the period between the date when the cause of action arose and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a sum paid before judgment, the date of the payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the sum for which judgment is given, the date of the judgment.

subsection.content: Rules of court may provide for the rate of interest and the method of calculation.

subsection.leadIn: In a judgment given for damages for personal injuries or arising out of the death of a person which exceed $30,000, the Court has, unless the Court is satisfied that there are special reasons to the contrary, to include simple interest at the rate the Court thinks fit on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: payment made before judgment, for the period between the date when the cause of action arose and the date of the payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other sum for which judgment is given, for the period between the date when the cause of action arose and the date of the judgment.

subsection.content: The defendant in proceedings for the recovery of a debt who pays the whole debt to the plaintiff (otherwise than in pursuance of a judgment in the proceedings) is liable to pay the plaintiff interest at the rate the Court thinks fit or rules of court provide on the debt for the period between the date when the cause of action arose and the date of the payment.
Interest in respect of a debt shall not be awarded under this section for a period during which, for whatever reason, interest on the debt already runs.
Interest under this section may be calculated at different rates for different periods.

In determining, for the purposes of section 32, 33, 36 or 37, whether an amount exceeds or is less than the amount specified in those sections, the Court shall not take account of any interest that may be ordered under this section or of any order for interest made under this section.
This section does not affect the damages recoverable for the dishonour of a bill of exchange.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: defendant (被告人) means the person from whom the plaintiff seeks the debt or damages;
plaintiff (原告人) means the person seeking the debt or damages.

subsection.leadIn: Judgment debts are to carry simple interest—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the rate the Court orders; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the absence of an order, at the rate the Chief Justice determines by order,

subsection.continued: on the total amount of the judgment debt, or on the part that for the time being remains unpaid, from the date of the judgment until payment.

subsection.content: Interest under this section may be calculated at different rates for different periods.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Extension of jurisdiction to grant injunctions and to make declarations

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall have jurisdiction to grant and to enforce injunctions of whatsoever nature and as the case may require and to make binding declarations of right—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in all matters affecting movable property, including money and choses in actions, where the amount or value thereof does not exceed $3,000,000; and (Amended 68 of 1973 s. 2; 79 of 1981 s. 2; L.N. 387 of 1983; 49 of 1988 s. 4; 28 of 2000 s. 25; L.N. 241 of 2003)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with respect to any apprehended distress; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in all matters affecting immovable property, including any right, licence or easement in, to, through or over any immovable property and any agreement, covenant or condition respecting immovable property, where the annual rent or the rateable value, determined in accordance with the provisions of the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116) or the annual value, whichever is the less, of the property does not exceed $320,000; and (Amended 68 of 1973 s. 3; 79 of 1981 s. 2; L.N. 387 of 1983; 49 of 1988 s. 4; L.N. 145 of 1992; 28 of 2000 s. 25)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in all matters of contract not falling within paragraph (a), (b) or (c) where the amount or value of the subject matter of the contract does not exceed $3,000,000, (Amended 68 of 1973 s. 2; 79 of 1981 s. 2; L.N. 387 of 1983; 49 of 1988 s. 4; 28 of 2000 s. 25; L.N. 241 of 2003)

subsection.continued: notwithstanding that any claim for damages or for any other relief or remedy which the Court is competent to grant shall be made in the proceedings. (Amended 35 of 1966 s. 4; L.N. 131 of 2018)

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in this section shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be deemed to confer admiralty jurisdiction upon the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prejudicially affect the provisions of section 48; or (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 25)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: empower the Court to grant any injunction or to make any declaration in such manner as to affect any process or proceeding of or in the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s52A
section.heading: Power of Court to impose charging order

subsection.content: The Court may by order impose a charge for securing the payment of any money due or to become due under a judgment or order of the Court on a judgment debtor’s property specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: In deciding whether to make a charging order the Court has to consider all the circumstances of the case and, in particular, any evidence before it as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal circumstances of the debtor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether any other creditor of the debtor would be likely to be unduly prejudiced by the making of the order.

subsection.content: This section applies to a judgment, order, decree or award however called of any court or arbitrator, including a court of justice outside of Hong Kong or arbitrator outside of Hong Kong, which is or has become enforceable, whether wholly or to a limited extent, as it applies to a judgment or order of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 25 (which provides that a writ of execution shall not issue against any partnership property except on a judgment against the firm) of the Partnership Ordinance (Cap. 38), a charge may be imposed by a charging order under this Ordinance only on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: an interest held by the judgment debtor beneficially—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in an asset of a kind mentioned in subsection (2); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under a trust; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: an interest held by a person as trustee of a trust (in this paragraph referred to as the trust), if the interest is in an asset of a kind mentioned in subsection (2) or is an interest under another trust and—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the judgment or order for which a charge is to be imposed was made against the person as trustee of the trust;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the whole beneficial interest under the trust is held by the judgment debtor unencumbered and for his own benefit; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 2 or more judgment debtors are all liable to the judgment creditor for the same debt and together hold the whole beneficial interest under the trust unencumbered and for their own benefit.

subsection.leadIn: The assets referred to in subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: land;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: securities of any of the following kinds—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: Government stock;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: stock of any body incorporated in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: stock of any body incorporated outside Hong Kong or of any state or territory outside Hong Kong, being stock registered in a register kept in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: units of a unit trust for which a register of the unit holders is kept in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: funds in court.

subsection.content: The Court may extend a charge to any interest, dividend or other distribution payable and any bonus issue in respect of the asset where the charging order is over an interest in an asset other than land.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: dividend (股息) includes a distribution for any unit of a unit trust;

stock (證券) includes shares, debentures, loan stocks, funds, bonds, notes, any other securities issued by the body concerned, whether or not constituting a charge on the assets of the body and any rights or options to subscribe for or be allotted any of them;

unit trust (單位信託) means a trust established to provide for persons having funds to invest, facilities for them to participate as beneficiaries under the trust in the profits or income arising from acquiring, holding, managing or disposing of property.

subsection.content: A charging order may be made either absolutely or subject to conditions as to notifying the judgment debtor or as to the time when the charge is to become enforceable, or as to other matters.
The Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128) applies to charging orders as it applies to other orders or writs issued or made to enforce judgments.
A charge imposed by a charging order has the same effect and is enforceable in the same courts and in the same manner as an equitable charge created by the judgment debtor by writing under his hand.
The Court may at any time, on the application of the judgment debtor or of any person interested in any property to which the order relates, make an order discharging or varying the charging order.

The Land Registrar shall, on the filing with him of a memorial and an office copy of an order under subsection (4) discharging a charging order registered under the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128), enter a discharge of the charging order on the register. The Land Registrar may issue certificates of the entry.

The Court may by order (whether interlocutory or final) grant an injunction or appoint a receiver in any action or proceedings in the Court and within its jurisdiction in which the Court considers it just or convenient so to do.
The order may be made either unconditionally or on the terms and conditions the Court thinks just.

The Court may grant an interlocutory injunction restraining a party to any proceedings from removing from the jurisdiction of the Court, or otherwise dealing with, assets located within the jurisdiction whether the party is or is not domiciled, resident or present within the jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may, on an application made at any time before, at, or after the hearing of an action or proceedings, grant an injunction to prevent any threatened or apprehended waste or trespass whether—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person against whom the injunction is sought is or is not in possession under any claim of title or otherwise, or (if out of possession) does or does not claim a right to do the act sought to be restrained under any colour of title; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the estates claimed by both or by either of the parties are legal or equitable.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may appoint a receiver by way of equitable execution in relation to all legal estates and interests in land. The Court may exercise the power to appoint a receiver—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to an estate or interest in land whether or not a charge has been imposed on that land under section 52A to enforce the judgment, order, decree or award in question; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in addition to, and not in derogation of, any power of any court to appoint a receiver in proceedings for enforcing a charge.

subsection.leadIn: Where an order under section 52A imposing a charge to enforce a judgment, order, decree or award has been registered under section 2 of the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128), section 3(2) of that Ordinance does not apply to an order appointing a receiver made either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in proceedings to enforce the charge; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by way of equitable execution of the judgment, order, decree or award or of so much of it as required payment of moneys secured by the charge.

subsection.content: A sum standing to the credit of a person in a deposit account of an authorized institution is deemed to be a sum due to the person for the purposes of jurisdiction of the Court to attach debts to satisfy judgments or orders for the payment of money.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to rules of court, the sum in the deposit account of an authorized institution is attachable even if any of the following conditions applicable to the account has not been satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that notice is required before any money is withdrawn;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that a personal application must be made before any money is withdrawn;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that a deposit book must be produced before any money is withdrawn;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that a receipt for money deposited must be produced before any money is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other condition prescribed by rules of court.

section.name: s52D
section.heading: No arrest or imprisonment without order

subsection.content: Subject to section 52E, a person shall not be arrested or imprisoned to enforce, secure or pursue a civil claim for the payment of money or damages except under an order of Court; and the Court shall have jurisdiction to make such an order for arrest or imprisonment only to enforce, secure or pursue a judgment for the payment of a specified sum of money.
An order for imprisonment under subsection (1) shall be for a period not exceeding 3 months.
The period mentioned in subsection (2) may be amended by resolution of the Legislative Council.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: The Court may, on application, discharge, vary or suspend an order for arrest or imprisonment made under this section, either absolutely or subject to such conditions as the Court thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The Court may make an order for arrest or imprisonment under this section subject to such conditions as it thinks fit, including conditions as to the time and place of execution of the order and the condition that the judgment debtor be released on the payment of the judgment debt and costs, the provision of security by him or on his behalf or on the surrender of his travel documents.

subsection.leadIn: This section shall not affect any jurisdiction of the Court to make orders of committal in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contempt of court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disobedience of a judgment or order of the Court.

section.name: s52E
section.heading: Prohibition on debtor leaving Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall have jurisdiction to make an order prohibiting a person from leaving Hong Kong (a prohibition order) to facilitate the enforcement, securing or pursuance of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a judgment against that person for the payment of a specified sum of money;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a judgment or order against that person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the payment of an amount to be assessed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: requiring him to deliver any property or perform any other act; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a civil claim (other than a judgment)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the payment of money or damages; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for the delivery of any property or the performance of any other act.

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall not make an order under subsection (1)(b) unless it is satisfied that there is probable cause for believing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person against whom the order is sought is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by reason of paragraph (a), satisfaction of the judgment or order is likely to be obstructed or delayed.

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall not make an order under subsection (1)(c) unless it is satisfied that there is probable cause for believing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a good cause of action;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person against whom the order is sought—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: incurred the alleged liability, which is the subject of the claim, in Hong Kong while he was present in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: carries on business in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is ordinarily resident in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that person is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: by reason of paragraph (c), any judgment that may be given against that person is likely to be obstructed or delayed.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: The Court may, on application, discharge a prohibition order, either absolutely or subject to such conditions as the Court thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The Court may make a prohibition order subject to such conditions as it thinks fit, including the condition that the order shall have no effect if the judgment debtor or person against whom the claim is made satisfies the judgment or the claim or provides such security as the Court may order.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: An order under subsection (1) shall lapse—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on the expiry of one month but the Court may, on the application of the judgment creditor or claimant, extend or renew the order for a period which does not exceed, with the initial period of one month and any other period of extension or renewal, 3 months; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on the service upon the Director of Immigration and the filing with the Registrar of a notice by the judgment creditor or claimant advising that the order is no longer required.

paragraph.name: b
