paragraph.content: The judgment creditor or claimant shall serve and file the notice mentioned in paragraph (a)(ii) as soon as reasonably possible after the order is no longer required.

subsection.content: A copy of an order under subsection (1) and any other order ancillary thereto shall be served on the Director of Immigration, the Commissioner of Police and, if he can be found, the judgment debtor or person against whom the claim is made.

Where the Court makes an order under subsection (1) prohibiting a person from leaving Hong Kong, any person who, having been served with a copy of the order or otherwise informed of its effect, attempts to leave Hong Kong in contravention of that order may be arrested by any immigration officer, police officer or bailiff.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: A person arrested under subsection (7) shall be brought before the Court before the expiry of the day after the day of arrest and the Court may—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case mentioned in subsection (1)(a), make such order, for the examination or imprisonment of that person, under rules of court, as is appropriate; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 28 of 2000 s. 27)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of any other person, make an order for the imprisonment of that person until the lapse or discharge of the prohibition order; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in any case, make an order discharging that person from arrest either absolutely or upon compliance with such conditions as the Court thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Section 71 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall not apply to this subsection.

subsection.content: The Director of Immigration shall not be liable for any failure to prevent any person against whom an order is made under this section from leaving Hong Kong.
The form of order under this section may be set by the Chief Justice. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 28 of 2000 s. 27)

The costs of and incidental to all proceedings in the Court, including the administration of estates and trusts, are in the discretion of the Court, and the Court has full power to determine by whom and to what extent the costs are to be paid.

Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1), the Court may, in accordance with rules of court, make an order awarding costs against a person who is not a party to the relevant proceedings, if the Court is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so. (Replaced 3 of 2008 s. 32)

In any civil proceedings before it, the Court may, in accordance with rules of court, by order disallow, or order the legal representative concerned to meet, the whole or any part of any wasted costs. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 23)

When determining whether or not to make an order under subsection (3), the Court shall, in addition to all other relevant circumstances, take into account the interest that there be fearless advocacy under the adversarial system of justice. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 23)

def.name: WastedCosts
def.leadIn: In subsection (3), wasted costs (虛耗訟費) means any costs incurred by a party as a result of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an improper or unreasonable act or omission; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any undue delay or other misconduct or default,

def.continued: on the part of any legal representative, whether personally or through an employee or agent of the legal representative. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 23)

subsection.def: In this section, legal representative (法律代表), in relation to a party to any proceedings, means a counsel or solicitor conducting litigation on behalf of the party. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 23)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the parties to a dispute have agreed on all the issues in dispute, including who is to pay the costs of and incidental to the dispute;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the agreement has been made or confirmed in writing;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no proceedings relating to the dispute have been commenced; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the parties have failed to agree on the amount of the costs of and incidental to the dispute.

subsection.content: Subject to any other Ordinance, either party to the agreement may commence proceedings for an order for the costs of and incidental to the dispute, in accordance with rules of court.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings commenced under subsection (2) or transferred to the Court under section 52C of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4), the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an order for the costs of and incidental to the dispute to be taxed or assessed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make an order awarding costs to or against any party to the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make an order awarding costs against a person who is not a party to the proceedings, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so.

subsection.content: A reference to costs in subsection (3)(b) and (c) is a reference to the costs of and incidental to the proceedings commenced under subsection (2) or transferred to the Court under section 52C of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4).
The Court has jurisdiction to make an order under subsection (3) if the amount of the party’s claim for those costs does not exceed $3,000,000. (Amended L.N. 131 of 2018)

subsection.def: In this section, Court (區域法院) includes the Registrar and a master of the Court.

section.name: s53B
section.heading: Transfer of costs-only proceedings to Court of First Instance

subsection.content: The Court may, either of its own motion or on the application of any party, order the transfer of proceedings commenced under section 53A(2) to the Court of First Instance.
An order may be made under this section at any stage of the proceedings.

section.name: s53C
section.heading: Scale of costs on which costs awarded under section 53A are taxed

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court has made an award of costs under section 53A(3), it may order that those costs be taxed in accordance with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Schedule 1 and Schedule 2 to Order 62 of the Rules of the District Court (Cap. 336 sub. leg. H); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the First Schedule and the Second Schedule to Order 62 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A).

subsection.content: Where an award of costs under section 53A(3) is made by the Registrar or a master of the Court, the power of the Court under subsection (1) in relation to those costs may be exercised by the Registrar or that master (as the case may be).

In any civil proceedings, the Court may call to its aid not more than 2 assessors specially qualified and may dispose of such proceedings, wholly or in part, with the aid of such assessor or assessors, but the decision of the judge shall be the decision of the Court.
The Court may determine the remuneration, if any, to be paid to an assessor in respect of his services. (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 30)
This section does not authorize the payment of remuneration to a person employed full time in any office of emolument of the Government. (Added 28 of 2000 s. 30)

section.name: s59
section.heading: Examination of witnesses outside the jurisdiction of the Court

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance has the same power to issue a commission, request or order to examine witnesses outside the jurisdiction of the Court for the purpose of proceedings in the Court as it has for the purpose of a cause or matter in the Court of First Instance.
The Court of First Instance may order that the proceedings be transferred to the Court of First Instance where an application is made to examine witnesses outside the jurisdiction of the Court.
The reasons for any judgment or order of the Court may be delivered orally or in writing. (Amended 1 of 1993 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Where the reasons for any judgment or order are delivered orally, those reasons shall be reduced to writing within 21 days after the hearing or the trial and the reasons so reduced to writing shall be signed by the judge. (Added 1 of 1993 s. 3)
Every party to the proceedings shall be entitled to a copy of any written judgment or order on payment of such fees as may be prescribed.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Death or absence of judge before conclusion of trial

subsection.content: Where a judge is prevented by death, absence or otherwise howsoever from concluding the trial of any cause, any other judge, with the consent of the parties, may proceed therewith and may give judgment therein and in so doing may act not only upon any further evidence adduced in the proceedings but also upon any evidence already received insofar as it has been recorded.

For the purposes of this section, the fact that a judge purports to proceed with an unconcluded trial in accordance with the provisions of subsection (1), shall be conclusive evidence that the former judge in such cause is dead, absent or otherwise not available.
Subject to subsection (3), an appeal can, with leave of a judge or the Court of Appeal, be made to the Court of Appeal from every judgment, order or decision of a judge in any civil cause or matter.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1B), an appeal lies as of right to a judge in chambers from a judgment, order or decision of a master in any civil cause or matter. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 28)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: Where rules of court provide that an appeal from a specified judgment, order or decision of a master lies to the Court of Appeal, the appeal may be made to the Court of Appeal with leave of a master or the Court of Appeal. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 28)
An appeal is subject to rules of court.
A person against whom an order is made pursuant to section 20, 29, 48B, 52D, 52E or 53(3) is entitled to appeal to the Court of Appeal without leave.

subsection.def: In this section, master (聆案官) means the Registrar, a deputy registrar or assistant registrar. (Added 3 of 2008 s. 28)

subsection.leadIn: Leave to appeal granted under section 63 may be granted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a particular issue arising out of the judgment, order or decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as the judge, the master or the Court of Appeal hearing the application for leave considers necessary in order to secure the just, expeditious and economical disposal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: Leave to appeal shall not be granted unless the judge, the master or the Court of Appeal hearing the application for leave is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appeal has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice why the appeal should be heard.

subsection.def: In this section, master (聆案官) means the Registrar, a deputy registrar or assistant registrar.

section.name: s63B
section.heading: Decision on leave to appeal final
section.content: No appeal lies from a decision of the Court of Appeal as to whether or not leave to appeal to it should be granted.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Powers of Court of Appeal on appeal

subsection.leadIn: On any appeal, the Court of Appeal may draw any inference of fact and may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order a new trial on such terms as it thinks just; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order judgment to be entered for any party; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make a final or other order on such terms as it thinks proper to ensure the determination on the merits of the real question in controversy between the parties.

subsection.content: On any appeal, the Court of Appeal may reverse or vary, in favour of a party seeking to support the judgment or order of the Court in whole or in part, any determinations made in the Court on questions of fact, notwithstanding that the appeal is on a point of law only, or any such determinations on points of law notwithstanding that the appeal is an appeal on a question of fact only.
On any appeal, the Court of Appeal may receive further evidence in accordance with the provisions of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A). (Amended 103 of 1970 s. 7; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.sourceNote: (22 of 1962 s. 40 incorporated. Amended E.R. 1 of 2013)

section.name: s65
section.heading: Procedure on appeal
section.content: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, every appeal from the Court to the Court of Appeal shall be brought in such manner and shall be subject to such conditions as are prescribed by the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A).
section.sourceNote: (22 of 1962 s. 41 incorporated. Amended 103 of 1970 s. 8; 25 of 1998 s. 2; E.R. 1 of 2013)

subsection.content: An application for a stay of execution on an appeal may be made at any time and shall, unless the Court of Appeal otherwise allows, be made in the first instance to a judge of the Court.

Without prejudice to the powers of the Court of Appeal, a judge, on any such application, may grant a stay of execution on such terms as to costs, payment of money into court, giving security for the prosecution of an appeal or otherwise as he shall think fit.

section.name: s66A
section.heading: Penalty for neglect of witness summons

subsection.leadIn: Any person summoned in manner prescribed as a witness in the Court who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses or neglects, without sufficient cause, to appear or to produce any documents required by the summons to be produced; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuses to be sworn or to give evidence,

subsection.continued: shall forfeit such fine, and serve such term of imprisonment not exceeding 2 years, as the judge may direct. (Amended 28 of 2000 s. 34)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Court cannot punish, under subsection (1)(a), a person summoned as a witness unless he has been paid or has had tendered to him at the time of service of the summons a reasonable sum for expenses, including in prescribed cases, compensation for loss of time. (Added 28 of 2000 s. 34)
Any person present in court who is required to give evidence but refuses to be sworn or to give evidence shall be punishable as aforesaid.

A judge may at his discretion direct that the whole or any part of any fine paid under this section shall, after deducting the costs, be applicable towards indemnifying the party injured by the refusal or neglect without prejudice to the right of the party so injured to institute civil proceedings in respect of the injury.

section.name: s66B
section.heading: Witness expenses
section.content: In any proceedings in the Court, a judge or the Registrar may order the reimbursement of a witness for any expenses reasonably and properly incurred by the witness.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Priority of Court of First Instance and court executions

subsection.content: Where writs have been issued from the Court of First Instance and from the Court or from the Court only, at the suit of different plaintiffs, against the goods of the same person, the right to the goods seized shall be determined by the priority of the time of delivery of the writ to the bailiff to be executed. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
The bailiff shall endorse on every such writ the date and time of the same coming to his hands for execution.

section.name: s68A
section.heading: Effect of writs of execution against goods

subsection.content: A writ of fieri facias or other writ of execution against goods issued from the Court binds the property in the goods of the execution debtor from the time when the writ to be executed is delivered to the bailiff.

A writ of execution does not prejudice the title to any goods of the execution debtor acquired by a person in good faith and for valuable consideration unless the person had, at the time when he acquired his title, notice that the writ or any other writ under which the goods of the execution debtor might be seized or attached had been delivered to and remained unexecuted in the hands of the bailiff.

The bailiff (without fee) on receipt of any writ of execution must endorse on its back the hour, day, month and year when he received it so that the time mentioned in subsection (1) can be determined.

subsection.leadIn: In this section and in section 68B—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: property (產權、財產) means the general property in goods, and not merely a special property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: bailiff (執達主任) includes any officer charged with the enforcement of a writ of execution;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any reference to the goods of the execution debtor is deemed a reference to property liable to attachment and sale in execution of a judgment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an act is treated as done in good faith if it is in fact done honestly, whether it is done negligently or not.

section.name: s68B
section.heading: Sale of property in execution of judgment

subsection.leadIn: The property of the judgment debtor is liable to attachment and sale in execution of a judgment other than—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shares in the capital or joint stock of any private company within the meaning of section 11 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (c), the tools (if any) of the trade of the judgment debtor; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the necessary wearing apparel and bedding of the judgment debtor and his family dependent on and residing with him, to a value, inclusive of tools and apparel and bedding, not exceeding $10,000.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (5), the purchaser of any goods that were seized from an execution debtor by the bailiff charged with the enforcement of a writ of execution and sold by the bailiff without any claim having been made to them acquires a good title to the goods.

subsection.leadIn: A person is not entitled to recover against the bailiff, or anyone lawfully acting under his authority for any sale of the goods or for paying over the proceeds prior to the receipt of a claim to the goods—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: except as provided by section 46 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless it is proved that the person from whom recovery is sought had notice or might by making reasonable inquiry have ascertained that the goods were not the property of the execution debtor.

subsection.content: This section does not affect the right of any claimant who may prove that at the time of sale he had title to any goods so seized and sold to any remedy to which he may be entitled against any person other than the bailiff or purchaser.
The Court may, subject to rules of court, set aside the sale of any immovable property in execution of a judgment on the ground of material irregularity in the conduct of the sale.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Relief against forfeiture by action for non-payment of rent

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1A), this section has effect where a lessor is proceeding by action in the Court to enforce against a lessee a right of re-entry or forfeiture of any land for non-payment of rent. (Amended 32 of 2002 s. 40)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Where during the term of a lease the application of this section has prevented a lessor from enforcing against a lessee a right mentioned in subsection (1), then during that term this section shall not be applicable again to prevent the lessor from exercising that right against the lessee unless the Court is satisfied that there is good cause why this section should apply in favour of the lessee. (Added 32 of 2002 s. 40)

The action ceases if the lessee pays into court all the rent in arrear and the costs of the action within the time prescribed by rules of court for acknowledging service of the writ. The lessee holds the land according to the lease without any new lease.

The Court is to order that the lessor be given possession of the land on the expiry of a period, not being less than 7 days from the date of the order, as the Court thinks fit if the Court at the trial is satisfied that the lessor is entitled to enforce the right of re-entry or forfeiture. (Amended 32 of 2002 s. 40)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: The Secretary for Development may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend the number of days specified in subsection (3) by substituting another number therefor. (Added 32 of 2002 s. 40. Amended L.N. 130 of 2007)

An order for possession lapses if the lessee pays into court all the rent in arrear and the sum the Court directs on account of the costs of the action before the date ordered for possession. The lessee holds the land according to the lease without any new lease.

The Court may extend the period specified in the order for possession at any time before possession of the land is recovered under the order. Subsection (7) does not affect the power of the Court under this subsection.

subsection.leadIn: An action, order or writ for possession does not lapse on payment into court under this section if the lessor is proceeding in the same action—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enforce a right of re-entry or forfeiture on any other ground as well as for non-payment of rent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to enforce any other claim as well as the right of re-entry or forfeiture and the claim for arrears of rent.

subsection.content: The order for possession may be enforced if the lessee does not within the period allowed under the order pay into court all the rent in arrear and the sum directed to be paid on account of the costs of the action. So long as the order remains unreversed the lessee is barred from all relief.

The Court is to suspend a writ for the possession of the land for the extended period if the Court extends the period under an order before possession can be taken after that period has expired. If, before the expiry of the extended period, the lessee pays into court all the rent in arrear and the sum directed to be paid on account of the costs of the action, the Court is to cancel the writ.

subsection.leadIn: This section does not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the power of the Court to enter final judgment where the defendant fails to give notice of intention to defend;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the power of the Court to make any order which it would otherwise have power to make as respects a right of re-entry or forfeiture on any ground other than non-payment of rent; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 58(4) of the Conveyancing and Property Ordinance (Cap. 219).

editorialNote.content: For the saving and transitional provisions relating to the amendments made by the Resolution of the Legislative Council (L.N. 130 of 2007), see paragraph (12) of that Resolution.

section.name: s69A
section.heading: Service of writ in lieu of demand
section.leadIn: The service of the writ in the action in the prescribed manner in a case where section 69 has effect stands in lieu of a demand and re-entry, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one-half-year’s rent is in arrear at the time of the commencement of the action;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the lessor has a right of re-entry for non-payment of that rent; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: insufficient distress has been found on the premises to secure the arrears then due.

section.name: s69B
section.heading: Relief against forfeiture by re-entry for non-payment of rent

subsection.content: This section has effect where a lessor has enforced against a lessee, by re-entry without action, a right of re-entry or forfeiture as respects any land for non-payment of rent, where the rateable value of the land, determined in accordance with the provisions of the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116), does not exceed $320,000. (Amended L.N. 131 of 2018)

The lessee may, at any time within 6 months from the date on which the lessor re-entered, apply to the Court for relief, and on any such application the Court may grant to the lessee such relief as the Court of First Instance could have granted.

section.name: s69C
section.heading: Interpretation and application of this section and sections 69, 69A and 69B

subsection.leadIn: In this section and sections 69, 69A and 69B—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an original or derivative under-lease; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an agreement for a lease where the lessee has become entitled to have his lease granted;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an original or derivative under-lessee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the persons deriving title under a lessee;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an original or derivative under-lessor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the persons deriving title under a lessor;

subsection.def: trial (審訊) includes the hearing of an application for summary judgment;
under-lease (分租租契) includes an agreement for an under-lease where the under-lessee has become entitled to have his under-lease granted;
under-lessee (承轉租人) includes any person deriving title under an under-lessee.

subsection.content: Section 69 or 69B does not affect the provisions of the Government Rights (Re-entry and Vesting Remedies) Ordinance (Cap. 126).

section.name: s70
section.heading: Solicitors
section.content: A solicitor admitted to practise in the High Court is an officer of the Court and subject to its jurisdiction to the same extent as in the Court of First Instance.

subsection.content: No action shall be brought against a judge for any act done by him in the execution of his duty until the act done by him has been quashed on appeal to the Court of Appeal or by the Court.

No such action shall be brought in respect of any matter within the jurisdiction of the judge unless it is expressly alleged that such act was done maliciously and without reasonable and probable cause and the burden of proof that the act was so done shall rest with the plaintiff in such action.

In any such action in respect of any matter over which by law the judge had no jurisdiction or in which he exceeded the jurisdiction conferred on him by this Ordinance or by any other enactment, it shall be a good defence that the act complained of was not done maliciously and without reasonable or probable cause and the burden of proof that the act was not so done shall rest with the judge.

Save under and in accordance with this section no action shall lie in any civil court against a judge for any act done in a matter over which by law he had no jurisdiction or in which he exceeded the jurisdiction conferred on him by this Ordinance or by any other enactment.

section.name: s71A
section.heading: Registrar may apply for order
section.content: The Registrar may, in case of doubt or difficulty, apply summarily to the Court for an order for the direction and guidance of a bailiff, and the Court may make such order in the matter as may seem just and reasonable.

subsection.leadIn: No action shall be brought against the Registrar for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done by any bailiff without directions from the Registrar; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any direction given to any bailiff with regard to the execution or non-execution of process if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: such directions are in accordance with an order from the Court under section 71A; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: no material fact is wilfully misrepresented or suppressed by the Registrar.

subsection.def: In this section, Registrar (司法常務官) includes a Master.

subsection.leadIn: The Rules Committee may make rules of court regulating and prescribing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the procedure, including the method of pleading in the Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the practice to be followed in the Court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the procedure and practice to be followed in the Registry of the Court; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any matters incidental to the procedure or practice.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the general nature of subsection (1), rules of court may be made for the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribing the procedure for the transfer of proceedings between the Court and the Court of First Instance, and between the Court and the Lands Tribunal; (Amended 3 of 2008 s. 46)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribing the jurisdiction of the Court which the Registrar may exercise (including provision for appeal against decisions made in the exercise of the jurisdiction);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: regulating matters relating to the fees and costs of proceedings (including proceedings in connection with the administration of estates and trusts) in the Court and matters incidental to the proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: prescribing in what cases absent persons having an interest in a cause or matter are bound by any order made;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: regulating the execution of the process of the Court, including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prohibiting judgment debtors and persons against whom civil claims are made from leaving Hong Kong and ordering the payment of compensation to them in prescribed circumstances;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: ordering judgment debtors or officers of corporate judgment debtors to appear for examination and their examination; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the arrest and imprisonment of judgment debtors;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: providing that, in any case where a document filed in, or in the custody of, the Registry of the Court is required to be produced to any court or tribunal (including an umpire or arbitrator) sitting elsewhere than at the Court—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it shall not be necessary for any officer, whether served with a subpoena in that behalf or not, to attend for the purpose of producing the document; but

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the document may be produced to the court or tribunal by sending it to the court or tribunal, in the manner prescribed in the rule, together with a certificate, in the form so prescribed, to the effect that the document has been filed in, or is in the custody of, the Registry,

paragraph.continued: and any such certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the facts stated in it.

subsection.content: The power to make rules of court under this section includes power to make rules as to proceedings by or against the Government.
Rules of court made under this section apply to all proceedings by or against the Government insofar as they expressly purport so to do.
In the exercise of his discretion, a judge may excuse a party from compliance with any rule.

section.name: s72A
section.heading: Rules for commencing proceedings for estates of deceased persons
section.leadIn: The Rules Committee may make rules of court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceedings to be commenced against the estate of a deceased person where a grant of probate or administration has not been made by the appointment of a person to represent the estate or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings purporting to have been commenced by or against a dead person to be treated as having been commenced by or against his estate whether or not a grant of probate or administration was made before their commencement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any proceedings commenced or treated as commenced in the Court by or against the estate of a deceased person to be maintained (whether by substitution of parties, amendment or otherwise) by or against, as the case may be, a person appointed to represent the estate or, if a grant of probate or administration is or has been made, by or against the personal representatives.

section.name: s72B
section.heading: Rules as to proof of facts and admission of statements in civil proceedings

subsection.leadIn: The Rules Committee may make rules of court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the means by which particular facts may be proved;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the mode in which evidence of the facts may be given;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the conditions subject to which oral expert evidence may be given.

subsection.content: The Court may act on a certificate purporting to be a certificate of a registered medical practitioner in deciding for the purposes of any rules made under this section whether or not a person is fit to attend as a witness.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding any enactment or rule of law under which documents prepared for the purpose of pending or contemplated civil proceedings or in connection with the obtaining or giving of legal advice are in certain circumstances privileged from disclosure, rules made under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enable the Court in civil proceedings to direct a party to disclose the expert evidence which he proposes to bring as part of his case at the trial to the other parties by the date specified in the direction (or a later date permitted or agreed under the rules); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prohibit a party who fails to comply with a direction under rules made under paragraph (a) from bringing in evidence under Part IV of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) any expert report that deals with matters specified in the direction except with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the general nature of subsection (1)(c), rules made under that paragraph may prohibit a party who fails to comply with a direction given under rules made under subsection (3)(b) from bringing any oral expert evidence dealing with matters specified in the direction, except with the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: A rule made under this section may make different provision—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for different classes of cases;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for expert reports dealing with matters of different classes; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for other different circumstances.

subsection.content: In this section references to an expert report are references to a written report by a person dealing wholly or mainly with matters on which he is (or would if living be) qualified to give expert evidence.

section.name: s72C
section.heading: Rules as to stop orders and notices

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: prescribed securities (訂明的保證物) means securities (including funds in court) of a kind prescribed by rules of court made under this section;

stop notice (停止通知書) means a notice requiring any person on whom it is served to refrain from taking any of the steps mentioned in subsection (4) in respect of any of the securities specified in the notice, without first notifying the person by whom, or on whose behalf, the notice was served;
stop order (停止令) means an order of the Court prohibiting the taking of any of the steps mentioned in subsection (4) in respect of any of the securities specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: The Rules Committee may make rules of court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court to make a stop order on the application of a person claiming to be entitled to an interest in prescribed securities; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the service of a stop notice by a person claiming to be entitled to an interest in prescribed securities.

subsection.content: Rules of court made under this section are to prescribe the person on whom a copy of a stop order or stop notice is to be served.

subsection.leadIn: The steps mentioned in subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the registration of a transfer of the securities;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for funds in court, the transfer, delivery out, payment or other dealings with the funds, or of the income on the funds;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the payment of a dividend, interest or otherwise for the securities; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for a unit trust, an acquisition of or other dealings with the units by a person or body exercising functions under the trust.

subsection.content: Rules made under this section may include incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions that the Rules Committee considers expedient, and may make different provision for different cases or classes of cases.

section.name: s72CA
section.heading: Rules as to costs and interest

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding sections 50 and 53, the Rules Committee may make rules of court for enabling the Registrar, in such circumstances as may be specified in the rules, to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disallow all or part of any costs to be taxed pursuant to a costs order made by the Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disallow all or part of any interest otherwise payable under section 50 on taxed costs, or reduce the period for which such interest is payable or the rate prescribed in section 50 at which such interest is payable; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: increase the rate prescribed in section 50 at which interest on taxed costs or costs of taxation is payable.

subsection.content: Rules made under this section may include incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions that the Rules Committee considers expedient.

subsection.def: In this section, Registrar (司法常務官) includes a Master.

subsection.content: The Rules Committee may make rules of court for the circumstances in which the Court may order a party to pending proceedings to make an interim payment of the amount specified in the order, either by payment into court or (if the order provides) by paying it to another party to the proceedings.

The rules made under subsection (1) may enable a party to proceedings who has made an interim payment under an order to recover the whole or part of the amount of the payment in the circumstances, and from the party to the proceedings, determined under the rules.
Rules made under this section may include incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions that the Rules Committee considers expedient.
This section does not affect the exercise of any power relating to costs, including any power to make rules of court relating to costs.

subsection.def: In this section, interim payment (中期付款) means a payment on account of any damages, debt or other sum (excluding any costs) which a party may be held liable to pay to or for the benefit of another party to the proceedings if a final judgment or order of the Court in the proceedings is given or made in favour of that other party.

subsection.content: This section binds the Government so far as any proceedings to which this section is applicable can be brought by or against the Government in accordance with the Crown Proceedings Ordinance (Cap. 300).

section.name: s72E
section.heading: Orders for provisional damages for personal injuries

subsection.content: This section applies to proceedings in an action in which a claim for personal injuries is made in which there is proved or admitted to be a chance that in the future the injured person will develop some serious disease or suffer some serious deterioration in his physical or mental condition as a result of the act or omission which gave rise to the cause of action.

subsection.leadIn: The Rules Committee may make rules enabling the Court in giving judgment in a case to which this section applies to award the injured person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: damages assessed on the assumption that the injured person will not develop the disease or suffer the deterioration in his condition; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: further damages at a future date if he develops the disease or suffers the deterioration.

subsection.content: Rules made under this section may include incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions that the Rules Committee considers expedient, and may provide for the injured person to elect whether or not to accept an award of damages assessed under the rules.

subsection.leadIn: This section does not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affect the exercise of any power relating to costs, including any power to make rules of court relating to costs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prejudice any duty of the Court under any enactment or rule of law to reduce or limit the total damages which would have been recoverable apart from the duty.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Judge may make rules for regulating— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 18)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the deposit, payment, delivery, and transfer in, into, and out of the Court of money, securities, and movable property of suitors;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the evidence of such deposit, payment, delivery, or transfer, and the investment of and other dealings with money, securities, and movable property in court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the execution of the orders of the Court; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the powers and duties of the Registrar with reference to such money, securities, and movable property.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the general nature of subsection (1), rules made under this section may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: regulating the placing on and withdrawal from deposit of money in court, and the payment or crediting of interest on money placed on deposit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determining the smallest amount of money on deposit on which interest is to be credited to an account to which money placed on deposit belongs;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: determining the time at which money placed on deposit is to begin and to cease to bear interest and the mode of computing such interest;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: determining the cases in which money placed on deposit is to begin and to cease to bear interest and the mode of computing such interest;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: determining the cases in which interest on money placed on deposit and the dividends on any securities standing in the name of the Registrar is or are to be placed on deposit; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: disposing of money remaining unclaimed in court. (Amended 20 of 2014 s. 27)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: securities (證券) includes shares. (Added 20 of 2014 s. 27)

section.name: s73A
section.heading: Amendments of limits of jurisdiction and other amounts
section.content: The amounts mentioned in sections 32, 33, 35, 36, 37, 49, 52, 53A(5), 68B and 69B may be amended by resolution of the Legislative Council.

section.name: s73B
section.heading: Rules in relation to jurisdiction under Sex Discrimination Ordinance

subsection.content: The Rules Committee may make rules regulating the practice of the Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction under the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480) and the forms of proceedings therein.

subsection.leadIn: The power to make rules under subsection (1) shall extend to all matters of procedure or practice or matters relating to or concerning the effect or operation in law of any procedure or practice in any case within the cognizance of the Court as to which rules of the High Court have been or might be made for cases within the cognizance of the High Court and shall include power to make rules— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as to proceedings by or against the Government; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as to the persons who may appear in, conduct, defend and address the Court in, any proceedings therein;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to make special provision for any proceedings in the Court where regulations made under section 89 of the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480) apply to the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Each party to any proceedings in the Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction under the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480) shall bear its own costs unless the Court otherwise orders on the ground that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proceedings were brought maliciously or frivolously; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there are special circumstances which warrant an award of costs.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of subsections (1) and (2), the power to make rules under this section shall extend to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribing the place or places which shall be the venue or venues for proceedings to which this section relates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requiring the judge or judges sitting at such venue or venues to give priority, to such extent as may be specified in the rules, to hearing and disposing of proceedings to which this section relates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: empowering any such judge, at any stage of any proceedings, of his own motion, to order that any claim which is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: beyond the jurisdiction of the Court; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: within the jurisdiction of the tribunal within the meaning of the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25),

subsection.content: The Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction under the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480) shall not be bound by the rules of evidence and may inform itself on any matter in such manner as it sees fit, with due regard to the rights of the parties to proceedings therein to a fair hearing, the need to determine the substantial merits of the case and the need to achieve a prompt hearing of the matters at issue between the parties.

Subject to subsection (5), any rule made in accordance with the provisions of this section may be made so as to modify, with respect to proceedings in the Court, any rule of law or practice as to the proof of any matter or as to the reception or admissibility of any matter in evidence.

No rule made in accordance with the provisions of this section shall apply to any proceedings by or against the Government except in so far as it expressly purports so to do. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (c), this section shall not of itself operate to prevent—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: under the provisions of any other section of this Ordinance; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: which relate, whether in whole or in part, to the jurisdiction conferred on the Court by virtue of the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any rules made under the provisions of any other section of this Ordinance from applying to and in relation to such jurisdiction;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where there is any conflict or inconsistency between—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any rules made under subsection (2)(b); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any law and practice regulating the description of persons who may appear in, conduct, defend and address the Court, in any proceedings therein,

paragraph.continued: then those rules shall, to the extent of that conflict or inconsistency, as the case may be, prevail over that law and practice;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where there is any conflict or inconsistency between any rules made under the provisions of this section and any rules made under the provisions of another section of this Ordinance, then those first-mentioned rules shall, to the extent of that conflict or inconsistency, as the case may be, prevail over those second-mentioned rules.

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that no rule made in accordance with this section shall empower the Court to hear and determine any proceedings involving any claim beyond its jurisdiction.

section.heading: Rules in relation to jurisdiction under Race Discrimination Ordinance

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to make special provision for any proceedings in the Court where regulations made under section 83 of the Race Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 602) apply to the proceedings.

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b

paragraph.name: b

paragraph.name: c

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: beyond the jurisdiction of the Court; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: within the jurisdiction of that tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: The Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction under the Race Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 602)—

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may inform itself of any matter in such manner as it sees fit, with due regard to—

subparagraph.name: i

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the need to determine the substantial merits of the case; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the need to achieve a prompt hearing of the matters at issue between the parties.

No rule made in accordance with the provisions of this section shall apply to any proceedings by or against the Government except in so far as it expressly purports so to do.
